Hello Ken-

As you know, I am interested in these issues. I would like to understand
your suggestions below more clearly, and your intuitions for them. Please
see my questions below.

> I would suggest putting such information in a centered locations in their own
> layers, or in other dimensions (as you suggest)

How do these two suggestions differ? When you suggest 'another layer' isn't
that just shorthand for 'another dimension'? For example, the only way you
can have two inputs with the same centering (e.g. X=0, Y=0) would be to have
them have different Z dimensions, which to me implies another layer (in the
geometric representation space).

Can you give examples your suggestions so I can conceptualize them?

More importantly, why do you think centering the nodes but putting them in
different layers/dimensions is the right way to go (versus just putting them
in their own area within the pre-existing dimensionality)?


>, and sticking with HyperNEAT
> overall.  It may work well actually to make things like health and ammo actual
> geometric dimensions.  However, you could also let them be single nodes that
> are alone in their own layers, or in parts of the input layer that are
> separated from the rest of it.
> 

I have basically the same questions here, as I don't get the difference
between these suggestions.

Sorry if I am just not thinking of something obvious.

-Jeff
> 
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, tansey@... wrote:
>> 
>> Hi Ken,
>> 
>> Thanks for the clarification.
>> 
>> As a follow-up, do you have any suggestions on how to handle mixed geometric
>> and
>> non-geometric data?
>> 
>> For instance, if you're evolving a bot for a FPS, you may have some geometric
>> representation of the world. However, there may also be other relevant
>> information like health or ammo. It seems like there are only three solutions
>> right now:
>> 
>> 1. Use regular NEAT and lose the regularity of the world.
>> 2. Use HyperNEAT and force the health and ammo information to be represented
>> as
>> extra dimensions even though they can be handled by a single input node.
>> 3. Evolve a HyperNEAT agent separately then use its input(s) as secondary
>> input(s) to a regular NEAT controller.
>> 
>> Is there a fourth approach? Or is there generally a preference for one of the
>> above three approaches?
>> 
>> Wesley
>> 
>> Quoting Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...>:
>> 
>>> Wesley, the main insight motivating r(x) is that it aligns the agent
>>> geometry
>>> with the team geometry.  That is, the left side of the agent is on the same
>>> side of the agent as the left side of the team, which is how it usually
>>> would
>>> be in the real world.  Nevertheless, you make a good point that the
>>> substrate
>>> could be 3D as an alternative.  There is nothing wrong with doing it that
>>> way
>>> and it does have its own advantages.  In fact, we have experimented with
>>> both
>>> approaches to laying out agents for multiagent learning (although only r(x)
>>> is in the GECCO paper), and both are valid.
>>> 
>>> ken
>>> 
>>> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Wesley Tansey <tansey@> wrote:
>>>> 
>>>> Hi everyone,
>>>> 
>>>> I am working on a project that needs a substrate of more than 2
>>>> dimensions. Looking at David and Ken's GECCO'08 paper, I would have
>>>> expected a 3d substrate for the heterogeneous agent experiment. Is there
>>>> some insight I'm missing behind using the special r(x) function rather
>>>> than making a 3rd dimension?
>>>> 
>>>> Wesley
>>>> 
>>> 
>>> 
>>> 
>> 
> 
>
